title: The best UK Valentine’s Day gifts for 2026: 38 thoughtful ideas that will last beyond 14 February | Valentine's Day | The Guardian
description: Skip the predictable and the perishable this year: from a double-cup flask to a table tennis set, we’ve handpicked gifts they’ll love long after the big day
Author: Lily Smith
Headline: Skip the predictable and the perishable this year: from a double-cup flask to a table tennis set, we’ve handpicked gifts they’ll love long after the big day
Content: Composite: Sandra Navarro/GuardianView image in fullscreenComposite: Sandra Navarro/GuardianThe FilterValentine's DayThe best UK Valentine’s Day gifts for 2026: 38 thoughtful ideas that will last beyond 14 FebruarySkip the predictable and the perishable this year: from a double-cup flask to a table tennis set, we’ve handpicked gifts they’ll love long after the big dayThe best flower delivery for every budgetLily SmithSun 1 Feb 2026 07.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 1 Feb 2026 07.02 ESTShareThe Guardian’s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Learn more.Valentine’s Day: love it or love to hate it, there’s no denying it can feel manufactured to make you spend your hard-earned cash on cheap stuffed toys, out-of-season red roses and unimaginative chocolates. But with the right gift, it can be a great opportunity to show your partner how much you care, and how well you truly know them.The Guardian’s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Learn more.To help you avoid tat that won’t last – or will get shoved to the back of a cupboard – we’ve rounded up 38 thoughtful ideas to last well beyond 14 February. From a massage candle and toys to spice up your sex life to a bakery guide and a two-person flask for your next adventure, our cliche-free guide will help you find a gift that’s original, personal and will definitely get you in their good books.The best Valentine’s Day gifts in 2026Put your cards on the tableView image in fullscreenWhat’s My Jam? card game£14.99 at John Lewis£14.99 at AmazonProve how well you know each other with this cute card game that’s all about guessing each other’s loves and hates. It’s suitable for two or more players, and would make a great addition to your next date night.A two-in-one candleView image in fullscreenLelo black pepper and pomegranate massage candle£29 at John Lewis£21.75 at AmazonThis candle is a real two-in-one: light it to set a romantic atmosphere, then use the melted wax as an oil for giving your partner a sensual massage – everything you need for a romantic night in.Coffee … and a cake?View image in fullscreenBritain’s Best Bakeries 2026£20.66 at the Guardian Bookshop£20.24 at AmazonIf your partner’s love language is coffee and baked goods, Milly Kenny-Ryder’s book of Britain’s best bakeries will give you a new list of locations to try.Say it with jewelleryView image in fullscreenDuo baguette birthstone ringFrom £14.99 at EtsyA piece of jewellery with a personal touch, this ring can be customised with both your and your partner’s birthstone for a truly sentimental gift.Ringing the changesView image in fullscreenMen’s silver ring£85 at MissomaIf he has an understated style or doesn’t usually wear much jewellery, then a simple silver ring is a failsafe gift. This one from Missoma is crowd-pleasing without being boring.For more, check out50 men’s autumn wardrobe updatesFor adventurersView image in fullscreenBlack+Blum double-cup flask£42.46 at Healf£49.95 at AmazonPerfect for outdoorsy couples, this one-litre flask comes with two cups that store on either end of it, and it will keep your drinks hot or cold for up to 24 hours. Ideal for sharing a lovely cup of tea on your next adventure.Buttery-soft lipsView image in fullscreenKiehl’sButtermask for lips£18.40 at Lookfantastic£23 at John LewisThis luxurious lip mask hits that gift sweet spot: something they’ll use but may not buy for themselves. Made with coconut oil and mango butter, this overnight treatment will leave their lips soft, hydrated and ready for a kiss.For cosy nights inView image in fullscreenPersonalised movie snack trayFrom £30.60 at EtsyFebruary is still staying-in month, so celebrate your love for snuggling on the sofa with a special tray to hold all your snacks. To make your next movie night feel even more special, customise the enamel tray with your names.Flowers that will lastView image in fullscreenStained glass flowers£12.80 each at EtsyFresh flowers are lovely, but they don’t last long enough. These stained-glass flowers are works of art and will last for ever. Buy them their birth flower as a small token or build a larger bouquet for a more standout gift.View image in fullscreenFreddie’s Flowers subscriptionFrom £75 for three months at Freddie’s FlowersHowever, if they really love real flowers, buy them a subscription to make the treat last beyond February. Freddie’s Flowers offers beautiful bunches of seasonal stems delivered monthly; it was rated the best subscription in Zoë Phillimore’s test of thebest flower delivery services.Cook up a stormView image in fullscreenPasta Evangelists pasta-making kit£50 at Not on the High StreetThis kit comes with two (1kg each) bags of flour, recipe cards and all the tools you need to make homemade pasta, including pasta cutter, rolling pin and gnocchi board. A wholesome activity for the romantic day itself, but also a gift that will keep on giving as you master making your favourite pasta dishes.Underwear to get your pulses racingView image in fullscreenMesh heart embroidery bralette£34 at Lemonade DollsMesh heart embroidery high-waisted brief£16 at Lemonade DollsFemale-founded brand Lemonade Dolls prides itself on making pretty underwear that puts comfort first. This see-through red mesh set with embroidered hearts is just the right mix of sexy and cute. It also does this design in abra for fuller busts(DD-G).View image in fullscreenUltimate trunks, pack of three£45 at David Gandy WellwearClassic and simple but sexy, these trunks from David Gandy’s Wellwear brand are made from a cotton-blend stretchy fabric, designed to be breathable and feel like a second skin.Comfort = blanketView image in fullscreenSilentnight weighted blanket£35 at MorrisonsIf they’re a person who appreciates cosiness, then a weighted blanket will level up their restful nights in. Jane Hoskyn rated this one from Silentnight the best budget option in her test ofthe best weighted blankets. “It was heavy enough to envelope me with satisfying pressure and genuinely helped calm me as I lay on my side to go to sleep,” she wrote.Love potion optionalView image in fullscreenOliveYou mug£12.50 at Oliver BonasIf you prefer just a “little something” gift for Valentine’s Day, then this mug is a cute and goofy way of showing your partner you love them. It’s a gift they can get a lot of use from, too.Tame those whiskersView image in fullscreenLe Labo beard oil, 60ml£58 at SelfridgesThis Le Labo oil will make their beard so soft that you’ll no longer complain about it scratching you. Made with sunflower, grapeseed and jojoba oil, this treatment protects, nourishes and smooths the hair.Rise and shineView image in fullscreenZero Japan coffee dripperFrom £33.35 at AmazonIf they’re a filter coffee drinker, this ceramic dripper comes in an array of cheerful colours to add some joy to their morning ritual.For more, readthe secret to barista-style coffee at homeFlirty fragrance …View image in fullscreenVyrao Ludeaux eau de parfum, 30ml£71.20 at Space NK£89 at Harvey NicholsVyrao’s gorgeous but distinct fragrances will have people asking the giftee what they’re wearing. Ludeaux is a balanced mix of peach, osmanthus, jasmine and magnolia that’s equal parts floral and sweet.View image in fullscreenMalin+Goetz Dark Rum eau de parfum, 50ml£71.20 at Space NK£89 at John LewisThis scent from New York-based brand Malin + Goetz will transport them to sunnier days, even in gloomy February. Upon first sniff it’s quite tropical, reminiscent of a piña colada thanks to notes of fruity plum, creamy milk and rum. More masculine notes of leather and musk stop it from feeling too gourmand, though, while spicier notes of amber and anise add warmth.… or bargain scentsView image in fullscreenM&S Sea Salt& Neroli eau de toilette, 100ml£8 at M&SThis eau de toilette from Marks & Spencer has been compared to Jo Malone’s Wood Sage & Sea Salt, but it’s a fraction of the price at £8. Neroli and musk add depth to invigorating sea salt for a scent that’s fresh and beachy but floral. M&S encourages layering fragrances from itsDiscover collectionto create a concoction that’s personal to you.View image in fullscreenM&S Smoked Oud eau de toilette, 100ml£8 at M&SA more masculine option from the same range, Smoked Oud is a warm and earthy scent with hints of musk and sandalwood. It’s very wearable and not as overpowering as aftershave, making it a great everyday scent that won’t stink out the entire train on their commute.Head to the loungeView image in fullscreenM&SAutograph men’s wide-leg joggers£40 at M&SFor nights in together, these wide-leg joggers are comfy and stylish. The elastic waistband and cotton material provide comfort, while the pin-tuck detail elevates them from your average slobby joggers.View image in fullscreenAdidas Originals women’s wide-legjoggers£45 at Adidas£45 at AsosMade from a soft fleece and with a relaxed fit, these joggers are the perfect attire for lounging on the sofa, carrying out errands … or going on snack runs.A trip down memory laneView image in fullscreenMini hardback photo book£26 at PapierWe’re all constantly taking photos on our phones, but we’re willing to bet you hardly ever look through them. Celebrate all your favourite memories in this mini photo book that you can both flick through and reminisce. The cute artwork on the front is also appropriately Valentine’s-y.An ace giftView image in fullscreenAndy Warhol playing cards£13 at King & McGaw£9.86 at AmazonThis pack of playing cards inspired by Andy Warhol’s pop art will add some fun and culture to your next game night.Have a toastView image in fullscreenHeart-shaped coupes£15 at M&SHearts are a Valentine’s cliche, but we couldn’t resist these cute coupes. They’re kitschy in the best way, and are perfect for toasting milestones in your relationship.Tea for twoView image in fullscreenTraditional treats hamper£60 at HampersFor edible treats that will last longer than a day, go for a hamper. This one is filled with traditional delights, from fruit cake and strawberry jam to lemon drizzle flapjacks and ground coffee, to keep them going for weeks.Relax and unwindView image in fullscreenEspa restorative bath and body oil, 100ml£28.80 at Lookfantastic£36 at John LewisEncourage them to take a moment for themselves with this aromatherapy oil that can be used directly on the body or in the bath. The blend of rose geranium, sweet orange, lavender and palmarosa screams “spa day”.Set the moodView image in fullscreenRechargeable mushroom lamp£23 at DuskWhen trying to create a romantic vibe, the big light is a no-no. This rechargeable mushroom lamp will create instant ambience in any room, and would be a great gift for anyone who appreciates a cosy atmosphere.Supreme date nightView image in fullscreenTable tennis set£14.99 at DecathlonIf you both want to unleash your innerMarty Supreme, why not try out table tennis together? This set comes with two bats, two balls and an adjustable net.Level up your snacksView image in fullscreenThe Snack Hacker recipe book£19.80 at the Guardian Bookshop£14.29 at AmazonIf your partner loves experimenting with different flavours or has a penchant for weird food combos, George Egg’s recipe book will help them take it to the next level. Egg promises “surprising combinations, unexpected ingredients and unconventional methods” to create dishes that shouldn’t work, but just do – from fish finger spaghetti to Twiglet brownies.Spice it upView image in fullscreenCoco de Mer Pure Delight orgasm balm, 20g£30 at Cult Beauty£30 at John LewisA tingly mix of menthol extract, almond oil, shea butter and avocado oil, this balm is designed to increase circulation to the clitoris and enhance orgasm. A fun present for your partner if you like to mix it up in the bedroom.View image in fullscreenTenga penile stimulating sleeve£23.40 at TengaThere’s long been a squeamishness about sex toys for penises, but this abstract-style penile stimulating sleeve from Tenga is pretty enough to break the stigma. If you and your partner enjoy experimenting with toys in the bedroom, then why not give it a go? “These toys give far more mind-blowing stimulation than a plain palm,” says sex writer Alix Fox in her guide toeasy ways to spice up your sex life.View image in fullscreenHera Flex rabbit vibrator£109 at Je Joue£105.62 at AmazonFox rated the Hera Flex the best rabbit in her test ofthe best vibrators, so you know this is a gift that you (and your partner) will be satisfied with. “It’s as flexible as a yoga master and both parts of it are poseable, allowing you to easily customise how it curves to fit your bits,” says Fox, meaning even if you aren’t entirely sure what works for your partner, they should be able to adjust the Hera Flex to suit them.Honour their favourite tippleView image in fullscreenPersonalised beer stein£17.99 at EtsyAdmittedly not the most romantic gift, but it’s definitely a sentimental one. These steins can be customised with the style of their favourite beer and their name. Some even allow you to incorporate your partner’s face into the logo.Cuddly collectibleView image in fullscreenHeart macaroonJellycat£28 at SmallableI know, I know, cuddly toys are a cliche Valentine’s Day gift, but hear me out: Jellycats have taken the world by storm, and many people now see these as a collector’s item. This cute little heart-shaped macaroon is part of the brand’s 2026 V Day collection.Active accessoriesView image in fullscreenBala Bangle wrist weights£39.49 at Healf£49.95 at John LewisIf being active is important to them, these aesthetically pleasing wrist weights are a great way for them to increase the intensity of their lunchtime stomp.A message from their idolView image in fullscreenGet Miriam Margolyes to record a personal Valentine’s message.Photograph: Murdo MacLeod/The GuardianCameo videoRange of pricesFor a gift that they won’t forget, Cameo is filled with all sorts of celebs that you can pay to record a personal message for your loved one. Prices vary widely depending on who you choose, but there’s a range of icons on there from Miriam Margolyes and Miranda Hart to Michael Owen and James Buckley.For more, read thebest letterbox giftsandthoughtful gifts that last – and won’t end up in landfillView image in fullscreenDon’t buy anything until you’ve read the Filter, the Guardian’s home for truly independent product reviews and recommendations. title: Guinness Open Gate Brewery, London WC2: ‘Absolute “will-this-do?” nonsense’ – restaurant review | Restaurants | The Guardian
description: A multi-multi-million-pound paean to ‘the black stuff’ turns out to be rather underwhelming
Author: Grace Dent
Headline: A multi-multi-million-pound paean to ‘the black stuff’ turns out to be rather underwhelming
Content: Guinness Open Gate Brewery, London WC2: ‘Non-challenging yet hearty menus.’Photograph: Beca B Jones/The GuardianView image in fullscreenGuinness Open Gate Brewery, London WC2: ‘Non-challenging yet hearty menus.’Photograph: Beca B Jones/The GuardianGrace Dent on restaurantsRestaurantsReviewGuinness Open Gate Brewery, London WC2: ‘Absolute “will-this-do?” nonsense’ – restaurant reviewA multi-multi-million-pound paean to ‘the black stuff’ turns out to be rather underwhelmingGrace DentSun 1 Feb 2026 01.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 1 Feb 2026 12.42 ESTShareThe newGuinness Open Gate Brewery, with its tours, gift shop and dining options, has appeared in Covent Garden, slap-bang in the centre of London’s most nosebleedingly expensive real estate.This multi-multi-million-pound paean to “the black stuff”, where Guinness disciples can make pilgrimage, has been on the capital’s horizon for what seems like an era. The project has been tantalisingly dangled as an opening for some years, then delayed umpteen times, because, quite understandably, erecting a purpose-built, gargantuan, multi-floor Willy Wonka’s Booze Factory in the West End of London for a corporate behemoth is no easy feat. Imagine the layers of global, bureaucratic, cross-platform multi-media team Zooms that had to happen to hone the ultimate Guinness experience. So many Is to dot and Ts to cross, particularly, because food is a central part of the venture, with two restaurants on site –The Porter’s TableandGilroy’s Loft– where exec chef Pip Lacey is serving non-challenging yet hearty menus, as well as acourtyard pie stallbyCalum Franklin.View image in fullscreenSafe bet: the ‘soft, crusty, scone-like’ Guinness soda bread at Open Gate Brewery, London WC2.Eventually, last December, Open Gate Brewery finally flung open its doors. Or, more accurately, it opened its many, many sets of doors, because Open Gate is not one site, like Willy Wonka’s Factory or even Madame Tussauds, where you step inside and leave the real world behind. Instead, it is spread over several streets. A shop here, a restaurant there, a street stall over here, which makes the whole thing rather underwhelming.Aside from a twinkly cobbled area beside the gift shop, there’s nothing very photo-worthy for tourists to flood social media with. This is where my alarm bells went off. The London Guinness experience is decidedly subtle. Apparently, they brew small-batch ales here, so can call themselves a brewery, but I saw no real push to sell them. Certainly not in the Porter’s Table, which I’d imagined would be a dark, sleek, modern, Irish-feeling restaurant with a welcoming Guinness for every diner, and an aura that you were in the home of that hallowed pint. I’d imagined servers drilled to flog Guinness, making a fuss of the pour, and how it pairs with specific meats and cheeses. Perhaps Hothouse Flowers, the Cranberries and the Chieftains would be playing in the background as I ate Guinness soda bread surrounded by chipper Irish-American tourists who adore their ancestry.View image in fullscreen‘Would have been dry without Guinness-peppercorn sauces and fermented chilli’: Guinness Open Gate Brewery’s platter of chicken, ribeye and triple potato Guinness and mushroom pie.The Guinness team have in fact spent millions making a restaurant that feels more like a Google HQ staff room with scarcely a mention of Guinness. No branded colours, no menu pairings, no concerted effort to sell you a pint. Maybe Guinness is so cool now – what with the TV drama and non-stop TikTok kids bleating on aboutsplitting the G– that its marketing agency thought the most powerful thing to do would be to quash anything as cheesy as serving the stuff.Be warned, however, if you do get stuck in on the pints in this ground-floor Guinness restaurant and need to spend a penny, the loos are on the fifth floor, and reachable only by lift. Guinness, let the record show, cannot organise a piss-up in a brewery.We ordered Guinness soda bread, which was served in some sort of weird iron safe. God knows why. It tasted wonderful: soft, crusty, scone-like. A round of “lyrical lager beer frickles” were pleasant enough, and a Porter’s beer melt withPaxton & Whitfield cheeseon brioche was essentially a McDonald’s cheeseburger made with toast. The patty was ungenerous, albeit nicely seasoned.View image in fullscreen‘Little more than some sponge’: Guinness Open Gate Brewery’s The Three Stouts dessert.Some ribeye – a scant 200g, served medium rare – and a half-chicken were good, if unmemorable, and would have been dry without Guinness-peppercorn sauces and fermented chilli, which cost an extra £4.50 for small pots. A Guinness-themed dessert called The Three Stouts was little more than some sponge with a bit of cream and chocolate caramel atop. Absolute “will-this-do?” nonsense.This was a puzzling experience. Why does this restaurant need a huge, noisy open kitchen to serve chicken and chips? How can the very respectedDevonshire pub, a short walk away in Piccadilly, be doing more for the image of Guinness than a hundred executives on six-figure wages organising this extravaganza? How did they create a gift shop with literally nothing worth buying, and in two short hours make me love the brandless? If you’re a tourist in London, go to Madame Tussauds instead.Guinness Open Gate Brewery, 28 Shelton Street, London WC2 (no phone). Open all week, Mon-Thurs 11am-11.30pm, Fri & Sat 11am-midnight, Sun noon-10.30pm. title: How to make mulligatawny – recipe | Food | The Guardian
description: Have you forgotten how good this spicy soup tastes? Here are nine easy steps to rediscovering the Indian-inspired winter warmer
Author: Felicity Cloake
Headline: Have you forgotten how good this spicy soup tastes? Here are nine easy steps to rediscovering the Indian-inspired winter warmer
Content: Felicity Cloake’s mulligatawny.Photograph: Kate Anglestein/The Guardian. Food styling: Lucy-Ruth Hathaway.View image in fullscreenFelicity Cloake’s mulligatawny.Photograph: Kate Anglestein/The Guardian. Food styling: Lucy-Ruth Hathaway.Felicity Cloake's masterclassFoodHow to make mulligatawny – recipeHave you forgotten how good this spicy soup tastes? Here are nine easy steps to rediscovering the Indian-inspired winter warmerFelicity CloakeSun 1 Feb 2026 08.00 ESTShareIhave yet to see anyone eating mulligatawny in an Indian restaurant – perhaps unsurprisingly, given that it’s a product of the British occupation, and the very name has an off-putting Victorian feel, which is a shame, because it’s aged a lot better than imperialism. Based, historians think, on the Madrassi brothmolo tunny, it’s a lovely, gently spiced winter soup that’s well worth rediscovering.Prep15 minCook50 minServes4-61 onion1 carrot1 parsnip1 celery stick2 tbsp ghee, or oil (eg, coconut)4 garlic cloves1 knob fresh ginger½ tsp cayenne pepper or mild chilli powder2½ tsp madras curry powder(see step 5)1½ litres good-quality chicken stock, or vegetable stock1 chicken thigh, bone in. skin on (optional; see step 1)150g masoor dal(AKA split orange lentils)4 tbsp flaked almonds(optional; see step 7)100ml hot milk, or water1 tbsp lemon juiceSalt1-2 tbsp fruity chutney(eg, mango; optional)1 small bunch fresh coriander, roughly chopped, to servePlain yoghurt, to serve1 A note on the meatView image in fullscreenThough often made with chicken, mulligatawny was also traditionally prepared with mutton or goat, and works well with lamb, too; any fairly tender cut of either will be fine (or, indeed, you could just add some cooked meat at the end). For a lighter dish, leave it out; to make it plant-based, just swap the fat and stock as suggested below.2 Prep the base vegetablesView image in fullscreenPeel and finely slice the onion. Trim and cut the carrot, parsnip and celery into fairly chunky dice, keeping them separate from the onion (there’s no need to peel the carrot and parsnip, unless they’re still filthy even after scrubbing). Note: the onions aside, the choice of vegetables is flexible, but do include at least one sweet thing – if not parsnips, try squash, swede or sweet potato.3 Sweat the onionView image in fullscreenPut the fat (I use ghee, but coconut oil or any other fairly neutral oil will do) in a large saucepan on a medium heat. Add the onion and fry, stirring occasionally, for about five minutes, until softened and beginning to turn golden. Meanwhile, crush the garlic and finely grate the ginger (no need to peel).4 Saute the other base vegAdd the carrot, parsnip and celery to the pan, and fry for another five or so minutes, until they’ve softened but still retain a little crunch. Scoop out a spoonful and set aside for now. Add the garlic and ginger to the pan, and cook, stirring constantly so they don’t colour, for a minute or so.View image in fullscreen5 Add the spicesSpoon in the cayenne pepper or mild chilli powder, and the curry powder, and stir for a minute. (Old-fashioned madras curry powder is still the best choice. If you don’t have it, recipes are available online, usually containing all or some of the following: coriander, turmeric, cumin, cinnamon, ginger, fennel, cloves and plenty of black pepper).6 Add the stock, chicken and dalView image in fullscreenPour in the stock – chicken is the most neutral option, but lamb or vegetable will do. Now add the chicken (preferably bone-in; this and the skin can come off later) or lamb, and the masoor dal. (Other varieties of dal can be substituted, but most pulses require longer cooking.)7 Simmer until cookedView image in fullscreenBring to a lively simmer, then turn down the heat, cover and simmer gently for 35 minutes, or until the dal is soft and the meat cooked through. While it’s cooking, soak the almonds in hot milk (plant-based is fine) or water. If you’d prefer to keep the soup nut-free, leave them out or substitute unsweetened coconut flakes.8 Blitz and flavour the soupLift the meat out of the pan. Blend the soup until smooth, then separately whizz the softened almonds and liquid to a puree and whisk into the soup; if it feels too thick, adjust the consistency with a little extra stock or water. Stir in the lemon juice and salt to taste, then add the chutney, likewise to taste, if you would prefer it to be sweeter.View image in fullscreen9 Finishing touchesPull the meat into strands, discarding any skin or bones, then stir the meat back into the soup along with the reserved sauteed vegetables. Divide between bowls and garnish with coriander. Mulligatawny is also rather nice topped with a dollop of plain yoghurt. This can be made ahead of time and stored in the fridge, and also freezes well.Explore more on these topicsFoodFelicity Cloake's masterclassSoupWinter food and drinkVegetablesBritish food and drinkMeatChickenfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: The kindness of strangers: while we waited outside in the rain, a young boy brought us hot tea and cake | Tasmania holidays | The Guardian
description: Our youthful enthusiasm was starting to falter when a child came out of a cottage with a basket, sent by his mum
Author: Katie Cunningham
Headline: Our youthful enthusiasm was starting to falter when a child came out of a cottage with a basket, sent by his mum
Content: ‘It showed me that most people are good and want to look out for their fellow man.’Illustration: Victoria Hart/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreen‘It showed me that most people are good and want to look out for their fellow man.’Illustration: Victoria Hart/Getty ImagesKindness of strangersTasmania holidaysThe kindness of strangers: while we waited outside in the rain, a young boy brought us hot tea and cakeOur youthful enthusiasm was starting to falter when a child came out of a cottage with a basket, sent by his mumRead more inthe kindness of strangers seriesRobert, as told toKatie CunninghamSun 1 Feb 2026 09.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 1 Feb 2026 18.10 ESTSharePrefer the Guardian on GoogleIt was 1974 and my school friends and I decided to backpack around Tasmania in the middle of winter – go figure. We were three mates in our late teens, without a clear plan.After arriving on the ferry, we hopped on a train owned by a mining company and travelled through the wild and unpopulated Tasmanian west coast to Queenstown. It was all forest and mountains, and so utterly freezing we sat in our sleeping bags on the train to try to warm up.The kindness of strangers: I was hitchhiking with nowhere to sleep when a man gave me his bed for the nightRead moreThe economy in Queenstown at the time revolved around the copper mine. I remember the shock of travelling through hours of forest to then arrive at a place where the hills had been denuded of vegetation from the pollution generated by the mine. The gloomy mood wasn’t helped by the bone-chilling cold and constant drizzle.Our idea was to hitchhike from Queenstown to our next destination, so we walked to a stretch of road on the outskirts of town and took up our position in front of the neatly kept miners’ houses to look for a ride. For a couple of hours, we waited with barely any cars passing.Our youthful enthusiasm was starting to falter when a young boy came out of a neat cottage with a basket. He said his mum thought we might like something to eat and drink. In the basket was a Thermos of tea, mugs and a container with some cake and biscuits. It was a balm on that freezing cold day.We were chuffed that someone had the kindness to think of the three scruffy guys loitering out the front of their house. It showed me that most people are good and want to look out for their fellow man. Eventually the drizzle stopped and we got our ride, but I’ve never forgotten the kindness of that stranger.What is the nicest thing a stranger has ever done for you?Share your experienceWhat's the nicest thing a stranger has ever done for you?From making your day to changing your life, we want to hear about  chance encounters that have stuck with you.Please share your story if you are 18 or over, anonymously if you wish. title: Dining across the divide: ‘Zack Polanski is articulate and charismatic, rather like Boris Johnson’ | Life and style | The Guardian
description: Their views differ on the Green party leader, but did the fellow Irish women agree on how to police demonstrations?
Author: Sam Wollaston
Headline: Their views differ on the Green party leader, but did the fellow Irish women agree on how to police demonstrations?
Content: Ruth (on left) and Moira. All photographs: Christian Sinibaldi/The GuardianView image in fullscreenRuth (on left) and Moira. All photographs: Christian Sinibaldi/The GuardianDining across the divideLife and styleDining across the divide: ‘Zack Polanski is articulate and charismatic, rather like Boris Johnson’Their views differ on the Green party leader, but did the fellow Irish women agree on how to police demonstrations?Sam WollastonSun 1 Feb 2026 07.00 ESTShareView image in fullscreenRuth, 30, LondonOccupationConsultancyVoting recordGreen, and a party member. Describes herself as “lefty”Amuse boucheIs an avid knitter. “Though I have yet to knit anything wearable”Moira, 76, LondonView image in fullscreenOccupationRetired. Does some voluntary workVoting recordFloating, but mostly Conservative and has been a party member. Describes herself as “slightly right of centre”Amuse boucheShe helped set up a cinema in an old libraryFor startersMoiraI was amazed I was having lunch with another Irish person. I’m from County Clare; Ruth is from Cork.RuthOriginally, we both said we’d do six months in London. I’m now a year and a half in and have no intention of leaving. Moira had that years ago.MoiraI ate coq au vin followed by creme brulee. Both were delicious, as was the lavender mocktail.RuthIt was this lovely, swanky French bistro – a real treat. I had ratatouille, which was so delicious. I didn’t drink because it was lunchtime and because we were going to be talking about some big topics.View image in fullscreenThe big beefMoiraWe got straight into Zack Polanski. I’ve always been interested in the environment and have voted Green in the past. Polanski is articulate and charismatic, rather like Boris Johnson. But because of that comparison – I thought Boris was a mistake as prime minister – I’m worried. Charisma is fantastic, but it needs depth and integrity.Dining across the divide: ‘For him it seems to come down to good immigrants and bad immigrants’Read moreRuthMaybe Polanski is an opportunist, but he’s a politician, so of course he’s going to seek opportunities to advance leftist policies. Why are the Greens pigeonholed: you’re only allowed to talk about climate politics? It’s just as much a political party as Labour or the Tories are. He’s talking about the social issues that concern people on the left who don’t currently have a home. I think he’s humble, he’s genuine and he’s willing to speak to people.MoiraI’m afraid I’ve been slightly turned off by the fact he once hypnotised a woman into thinking she had augmented her breasts! But I am concerned about housing; Ruth said she doesn’t think she’ll own a property, certainly not in London. There’s something radically wrong when a well-educated, hard-working person of 30 cannot see their way to owning property.RuthHis economic policies – the wealth tax and so on – are getting a lot of flak, but he’s handling it well. Economics is not his background – he’s not an expert, he’s saying he doesn’t have all the facts and figures to hand. But he’s human, he’s trying. That’s what this country needs: people who are trying and putting themselves on the line.View image in fullscreenSharing plateMoiraThe Irish don’t fall out with each other over opposing opinions. I think it’s partly because of space: the country is small and your chances of actually knowing the person you’re disagreeing with are high.RuthI thought there would be more bickering about things we disagreed on, but there was such a warmth. Moira is open-minded and interested in what other people think. But I don’t think I persuaded her to go back to the Greens!View image in fullscreenFor aftersMoiraOf course I agree on the right to free speech and to protest, but I wonder whether we’re spending too much money policing demonstrations. I propose the activists are asked to contribute for some of the policing and costs involved in closing off streets and damaging business. A tenner a head, say.RuthThe trouble with that scenario is it becomes a privileged system: protesting is all well and good but only if you can afford it. I would say there are too many police at Palestine solidarity marches. And how are you going to enforce this payment system?View image in fullscreenTakeawaysMoiraI had resigned myself to finding somebody dogmatic, but Ruth was lovely. I wish I had been as charming, positive and powerful when I was her age. I absolutely loved it.RuthI thought I might be more offended, but I came away from the experience with such fondness for Moira. We didn’t swap numbers, but if I saw her on the street I’d be so happy.View image in fullscreenAdditional reporting: Kitty DrakeMoira and Ruth ate atLe Petit Citron, London W6Want to meet someone from across the divide?Find out how to take partExplore more on these topicsLife and styleDining across the divideSocial trendsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: PMDD is ruining my life. What can I do? | Health & wellbeing | The Guardian
description: You’re already doing all the right things for your premenstrual dysphoric disorder, but perhaps it’s time to ask others for more help
Author: Annalisa Barbieri
Headline: You’re already doing all the right things for your premenstrual dysphoric disorder, but perhaps it’s time to ask others for more help
Content: Illustration: Alex Mellon/The GuardianView image in fullscreenIllustration: Alex Mellon/The GuardianAsk Annalisa BarbieriHealth & wellbeingPMDD is ruining my life. What can I do?You’re already doing all the right things for your premenstrual dysphoric disorder, but perhaps it’s time to ask others for more helpAnnalisa BarbieriSun 1 Feb 2026 01.00 ESTLast modified on Sun 1 Feb 2026 07.14 ESTShareI’m 32, andwas recently diagnosed withpremenstrual dysphoric disorder(PMDD),though I suspect I have had it for aroundfive years.Itseverely affects every area of my life.For10 days every monthI becomeirritableand impatient, and have debilitating brain fog. At my worst,I am depressed, with uncontrollable crying and suicidal ideation. I go to weekly therapysessions,takea variety ofsupplements,and live a healthy lifestyle – exercise, minimal alcohol, eating well, etc, but all thesehabits become almost impossibleduring myluteal phaseafter ovulationand I feel as though I am completely stuck.When I am not in my luteal phase, I love life. And then it all comes crashing down: I want to leave my job, break up with my partner, ignore my friends.I struggle to share thisexperiencewith anyone or ask for help because the condition ischronicallyunder-recognised and under-researched. SometimesIeven trick myself into thinking maybe it isn’t real. Iincreasingly feel I am burdening my partner as they are almost the only person I can be totally myself with.When I am at my best, I forget I even have the condition. When my period comes, it is as if I have had a brain transplant – I am a whole new woman. And then the countdown beginsuntil the next luteal phase. How can I live the next 20 yearslike this?That’s a lot to deal with. You’re right that PMDD is chronically under-researched (like so many women’s health issues). It has existed for a long time but was only recently been classified as a disorder.I took your problem to Dr Sophie Behrman, a psychiatrist who recently set up an NHS menopause and menstrual health clinic in Oxford. Her book Menopause, Menstrual Cycles and MentalHealthcomes out later this year. She told me it’s estimated that 1-3% of women get PMDD and it can happen at any time during their menstrual life. It is a mental disorder which causes severe psychological (and sometimes physical) symptoms in the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.With PMDD, it’s not that you have an abnormal balance of hormones in your body, but how your brain reacts to themYour reflection that after your period it’s like you’ve had a brain transplant is actually very astute. With PMDD, it’s not that you have an abnormal balance of hormones in your body, but how your brain reacts to them, and specifically to the falling progesterone levels before a period. The result is that people with the disorder end up feeling irritable, anxious, depressed and impulsive.‘Rage would bubble out of nowhere’: my battle with a premenstrual disorderRead moreBehrman said you are already doing a lot that can help. There’s evidence that a good, wholefood diet and exercise can be really beneficial (though I know it isn’t always easy to maintain), and supplements can help. It would be irresponsible to recommend anything specific or suggest other surgical or pharmaceutical steps but, if symptoms don’t improve, go back to the person who diagnosed you and ask what might happen next. Cognitive behavioural therapy can be helpful. Behrman also mentioned the importance of peer support. You could look at the websiteiapmd.orgfor more information.The “good” news is that you already have a diagnosis. As it’s a relatively new named disorder, lots of women have to do their homework before visiting a doctor armed with information.I’m so pleased you have a supportive partner, but I would like to gently urge you to share your condition (for it is real) with some trusted others. It’s tiring having to educate people, but sometimes that falls to us to do. Then they can support you – because you are worthy of support.In the UK and Ireland,Samaritanscan be contacted on freephone 116 123, or emailjo@samaritans.orgorjo@samaritans.ie. In the US, you can call or text the988 Suicide & Crisis Lifelineat 988 or chat at 988lifeline.org. In Australia, the crisis support serviceLifelineis 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found atbefrienders.orgEvery week, Annalisa Barbieri addresses a personal problem sent in by a reader. If you would like advice from Annalisa, please send your problem toask.annalisa@theguardian.com. Annalisa regrets she cannot enter into personal correspondence. Submissions are subject toour terms and conditions. The latest series of Annalisa’s podcast is availablehere.Comments on this piece are pre-moderated to ensure the discussion remains on the topics raised by the article.
